qas.question: Other than the bit rate and the difficulty of the signal, what can also affect the quality of an MP3 file?
The MP3 standard allows encoders to have a lot of freedom with which aspect of encoding?
As a result of the freedom, different encoders can result in different quality even if which aspect of the file is the same?
An example shown has a low range quality score of what value?
To compare qualities, sound files are evaluated on a scale that ranges from 1 to what?

context: Besides the bit rate of an encoded piece of audio, the quality of MP3 files also depends on the <a0_0>quality of the encoder<a0_0/> itself, and the difficulty of the signal being encoded. As the MP3 standard allows quite a bit of freedom with <a1_0>encoding algorithms<a1_0/>, different encoders may feature quite different quality, even with identical <a2_0>bit rates<a2_0/>. As an example, in a public listening test featuring two different MP3 encoders at about 128 kbit/s, one scored 3.66 on a 1–<a4_0>5<a4_0/> scale, while the other scored only <a3_0>2.22<a3_0/>.
